comments.commentBody:
Learned to behave
....................................
No children learn to be wary of those that are larger them. They also learn that it is okay to beat up someone that is smaller and weaker than them.

Beating children is for the lower classes and the poorly educated. Adults in the lower classes and poorly educated get back at the world by beating their children.
What are you talking about?  He is still being paid, so he is deprived of nothing guaranteed him by contract with or without due process.

Ahh! The good old days! If I walked up to a child on the street and started "paddling" them, I would be arrested and prosecuted in a "New York minute."
But if it's "my" child I can take a tree branch to them and I'm teaching them something?

couple firm swats on the bottom
..........................................
I grow tired on the idea that its is okay for parents to hit children.

If it is alright for a parent to hit a child why is it not alright for that child to go out and hit a smaller child.

If it is alright for a parent to hit a child why is it not alright for that child to use a knife on another child if they are angry with that child.
Time to recognize that hitting children just teach them it is okay to be violent.
At this rate I may just be able to get on the no-travel squad of one of these teams even though I last played intramural in 1969.
Why, other than the fact that media is doing it, do you feel this is attached to a sport. That is a serious question.
What is your point? NFL players may have an overall lower arrest rate, though, NFL players don't need to steal to get food and drugs, like less fortunate ordinary men.
If true, I wonder if it's because NFL players are generally so non-violent and law abiding, or if it's because well-known athletes are treated differently by the cops and courts.   :

Okay, except that the article you cite from The New York Times states that the data set used is imperfect. Additionally, there are some crimes that are vastly underreported, such as sexual assault and domestic violence, resulting in fewer arrests and prosecutions. Moreover, I suspect that there are other factors at play such as preferential treatment that lets players off the hook for certain offenses. Does this mean that the arrest rate for NFL players is lower, the same or higher than the general male population? We still don't have enough accurate data to come to a solid conclusion.

The media can't tell us enough about every NFL player who has a legal problem.  What the NYT et al won't tell you is that the arrest rate for NFL players is significantly less than that of the general population of 20-something aged men.
How is the NFL to blame for this behavior?
De-activate the players involved and then let their cases go through the judicial system.
Perhaps before Goodell is fired, someone in THE NFL echelon could test all its players for steroid blood levels, hmmm?  Seems pretty clear to me.

As the felony arrests mount the NFL finds itself in a quandary. I have a suggestion, since they seem unable to enforce civil behavior on so many of their players: Field a team of 8 or 9 players who play both offense and defense. There must be that many players who don't beat their wives, girlfriends or children.
"You won't change anything by just punishing a few football players." ????? Are you recommending that they get a free pass?

A violent society like ours promotes violence.  You won't change anything by just punishing a few football players.  The law says it's against the law.  That's saying nothing about violence except that it is against the law.  Does this sound circular?

neither augustine nor jung has ever been accused of domestic violence.
this is not about right or wrong/my country, but simply about violence at home.

This kind of comment is unhelpful and detracts from the important conversation that is happening around domestic violence and child abuse. I think it's great that people are stepping forward to say that this kind of behavior is completely unacceptable. I don't abuse children, family members or partners, and I don't think it's self-righteous to say that. I think it solidifies norms when large groups of people come together to say that this is not okay, we don't do this.

Let's keep the focus on the real problem: domestic violence abusers, and the organization that has previously and continues to enable their odious behavior, with ineffective and indecisive policy and an attitude that suggests they are most concerned with keeping their players on the field.

I read the comments to this article and think doesn't it FEEL great to be all self-righteous and superior.

Meanwhile, I think I'll go turn on the tv or go to the movies or play a video game (or watch our politicians lusting to kill) where I can wallow in sex and violence and criminality while simultaneously pretending that the cultural milieu has nothing whatsoever to do with the sex or the violence or the criminality in society.

Isn't it great to pretend that it's not about US. Nope, it's about THEM -- i.e. all those "others" who are depraved and indifferent and dysfunctional. Unfortunately, though, there is story after story after story (and oh-so many untold stories) which suggest that maybe, just maybe it's about all of us.

Time to wake up America and read ... well, almost any thinker from Augustine to Jung who ain't quite so sanguine in the comforting conviction that I'M good and holy and righteous and THEY ain't.

You are right - this is about crimes!  Not PERCEIVED crimes.  Real ones.  Crimes hidden away and covered up.  Does anyone really believe that Peterson's child should  be within arms reach of Peterson during the months or even years it will take to get Peterson processed by our "justice system"?  Or Ray Rice should ever be allowed near a female?  Get real!
And apparently the mother of the 4-year-old held the boy by his wrist so he couldn't get away. How can anyone torture a child? I just have never been able to understand this.
He is what mind- altering Republicanism has wrought.
Self-awareness is the first step.  But if the person "gets away" with what they are doing, there may not be enough motivation for them to take that route.

Ah, another public figure who amazes us that he is a public figure who is called upon to make ethical decisions affecting the rest of us. But, alas, who is perfect? Clergy run off with the organist or play with young boys. Football players beat up their spouses or children. Apparently there are judges who also do violence against a female. Wealth or education or power only make "getting away" with unacceptable, inappropriate, wrong behavior more probable. Yes, sex is likely the least of it for two consenting adults. But, the egotism, pride, and self hypnotic sense that what I do matters is delusional.

Another NFler charged with a serious crime. These big guys seem to find trouble easily.

If anyone is "disciplining' their child, I think an accurate gauge of whether you are crossing the line into the area of abuse would be to just ask yourself, "How mad would I be if the other parent/ babysitter/neighbour/school bus driver/teacher/troop leader/coach/daycare provider did this to my kid"? If you realize you would kill, call the police, or confront someone else for using that method on your child, it is possibly more abusive than correctional.
"The latest polls have suggested the result is too close to call." http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-scotland-scotland-politics-29231440

That any modern rational parent could conclude that hitting or striking their child for any reason, most especially meting out punishment to a child who may have not the remotest understanding of how they had transgressed or upset the adult is mindless child abuse. Excuses for physical punishment of children, including that the parent was similarly punished is not an excuse. In fact that any parent could even articulate a justification for taking a switch or a belt or a bare hand to a child as an act of punishment should be punished as assault and battery to the fullest extent of the law.

My Dad was the second youngest of eleven children, born in 1906. The first six were girls and then came five boys. None were ever physically punished or abused. My Dad continued the tradition successfully with his six kids. My two sons never experienced physical punishment and are now 39 and 36 year old highly successful, well educated, still great athletes, and married to great young women and I have one grandchild, a year old yesterday who will be the fourth generation to be brought up with love, pride and respect.

So sad you think this way....
Have you heard of Croatia ? The Serbs tried to get tough.
Have you heard of America ? England tried to get tough.
Difficult, but sometimes "true" democracies succeed.
( Even if this concept is pretty much unfathomable to most Americans. )

Let's not talk only of American's slave holding ancestors. There is probably no country on earth that benefited more from the slave trade than Great Britain.  Every slave brought to the North American Colonies and the British Caribbean holdings was transported on British ships and sold to British colonists before the US even existed.  Slaves, molasses and cotton made the industrial mill cities of England very rich.  And let's not forget that the British tacitly supported the Confederate States during the Civil War.  So tell me now, are you absolutely certain of what your ancestors did?
Ironic, eh? I think most English are concerned about how terrible it would be for England to be without Scotland, with nary a concern about Scots.

I think you proved my point. Plus your statement about Canadians barely acknowledging a relationship even existed (with UK) is mystifying since Canada's sovereign is still affirmatively (after periodic debate about change) the Queen of United Kingdom.
You and many are over romanticizing it. Many Scots were allied with the English. That's how the Union became possible. Don't forget that English and Scottish died together in WWI and WWII.

In years past many a hero, or a fool in some eyes, died for Scotland to be free. It is the highest historical moment for a People to chose to be free and stand alone, or be part of another country. That choice usually comes far between, after decades of revolution and thousands dead. May Scots take this opportunity because it truly is precious.
Although the economy may struggle it won't be because it would be like Greece as Greece does not have its own currency and according to Great Britain Scotland won't be allowed to use the pound.
